pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:0.5: 55. The training rule on with food
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying in the Bhagga country at Susumāragira in the Bhesakaḷā Grove,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.2: monks in the Kokanada stilt house received the drinking-water vessel with hands soiled with food.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.4: “How could the Sakyan ascetics receive the drinking-water vessel with hands soiled with food? They are just like householders who indulge in sensual pleasures.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.5: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.6: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.7: “How can those monks receive the drinking-water vessel with hands soiled with food?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.8: “Is it true, monks, that they do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.11: “… How can those foolish men receive the drinking-water vessel with hands soiled with food?
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.12: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.13: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.14: ‘“I will not receive the drinking-water vessel with a hand soiled with food,” this is how you should train.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.15: One should not receive the drinking-water vessel with a hand soiled with food.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.16: If a monk out of disrespect receives the drinking-water vessel with a hand soiled with food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.22: if he receives it with the intention of afterwards washing it or getting it washed;
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.25: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-sk55:1.26: The fifth training rule is finished.
